captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Ah, the signs of summer. It&#39;s broad daylight 
at 5am, the local frustrated housewives are

wearing hot pants to greet the pool cleaner, and 
Yahtzee&#39;s so starved for new releases he&#39;s playing

shit like Wuthering Waves. I caught a preview of 
Wuthering Waves at GDC this year. We sat down in

a booth slathered with anime babes and literally 
the first words out of the PR dude&#39;s mouth were

&quot;It&#39;s not the same as Genshin Impact.&quot; And that 
should tell you everything you need to know,

frankly. An exasperated marketing person described 
it as very specifically not something, ergo,

it is absolutely that thing. An Epic Games store 
exclusive free to play action RPG in a Breath of

the Wild-esque open world that funnels players 
towards a monetised gambling system through

the strategic use of anime babes in very short 
skirts. In the sense that a toothless trailer park

prostitute could be said to make &quot;strategic 
use&quot; of crystal meth. You start the game,

you login with that one email address you 
barely use but keep for situations like

this as a sacrifice to the gods of spam 
and phishing scams, and then you&#39;re asked

to choose your protagonist. Your options are 
the female character, wearing a bikini top,

hot pants, thigh boots and a couple of strips 
of cloth that appear to have been randomly

stapled to what little space was available, or 
a male character, wearing jeans and a T-shirt.

And if that doesn&#39;t do enough to immediately set 
the tone, the first thing you see after you wake

up with the inevitable protagonist-grade amnesia 
is two hot anime babes. One blandly nice one in

blue with big tits and one cheerful free-spirited 
one in red with big tits. Who take one look at

you and declare you to be a super special hero 
from the sky and they need to take you back to

their home city to introduce you to three or 
four additional hot anime babes with big tits.

I don&#39;t think it would be any exaggeration to 
say that every halfway important character in

Wuthering Waves is an anime babe who dresses 
like they covered themselves in velcro and

ran at full speed into a market stall full 
of high-end artisanal bookmarks. And every

now and again I&#39;d look about myself and go 
&quot;Boy, it&#39;s lucky you&#39;ve all got different

haircuts. If you were all at the spa in head 
towels and identical bathrobes I would never

be able to tell you fuckers apart. Oh, you&#39;re the 
basically nice emotionally stunted occasionally

quirky one with badass fighting skills? 
Can I put this post-it note on your head?&quot;

Look, I&#39;m not shaming the intended audience 
for liking anime girls with big tits. Across

my teenage years I must&#39;ve personally expelled 
enough white wee-wee over big titty anime girls

to immerse a fully grown horse. But that&#39;s porn. 
And I have trouble understanding the appeal of

wall-to-wall anime babes in a non-pornographic 
context. Feels like going to one of those Japanese

host clubs where you pay attractive people to 
sit around not fucking you all evening. Bitch,

I could go to any fucking bus shelter and meet 
a bunch of people who won&#39;t fuck me for free.

Anyway the point is, I wouldn&#39;t be down on 
Wuthering Waves for being waifu-centric,

but I will be down on it for being 
completely fucking tedious. Which is,

if anything, brought into sharper relief by the 
waifu-centricity. It&#39;s like having a dream about

all the pinup girls on your teenage bedroom walls 
coming to life and wanting to talk you through

your civics coursework. Incidentally, how the fuck 
does one &quot;wuther&quot; something? OK, I looked it up,

and apparently it means &quot;to move or shake 
vigorously.&quot; Which I guess a &#39;wave&#39; could do.

So that clears that up. Although it&#39;s opened fresh 
questions as to how it could apply to &quot;heights.&quot;

Going through the story of Wuthering Waves is 
like going to the DMV to renew your license

immediately after a major systems crash. You 
arrive at Main City Ville and your two hot

anime babes go &quot;Oh you need to go to city hall 
to meet the anime babe governor,&quot; which you do,

but then the hot anime babe at the front 
desk goes &quot;Sorry, she&#39;s in an appointment,

but she asked you to be given a leaf, a puzzle 
box and a Cadbury&#39;s Creme Egg.&quot; So then you

have to take those to the hot anime babe chief 
scientist at the research centre who&#39;s like &quot;We

will now analyse these three objects for you. Feel 
free to stand around admiring the room for a few

minutes.&quot; This literally happens. Just imagine 
it with about nine thousand extraneous lines of

dialogue spread across it. And occasionally the 
game fading to a black screen with white text

describing what a character is doing I assume 
because if they actually animated them all the

dangly bits on their outfit would fly up and 
knock someone&#39;s eye out. Then you finally get

an objective out in the world and when you get 
there a sinister villain kidnaps your friend

and goes &quot;A ha ha! Now we will fight! As soon 
as you have listened to me gab off for twenty

minutes and collected and filled out forms A, C 
and F29 from the offices to your left and right.&quot;

Then of course before the main plot continues we 
have to do side stuff until we get to level 15

and provide at least two proofs of address. 
And there was this entire side story where

I had to do a fucking mine inspection or 
something throughout which the game didn&#39;t

even tokenly spawn any monsters to fight or 
traversal sequences. And when I am fighting

monsters and grappling hooking around it feels 
like I&#39;m pissing about in the soft play area

attached to a government immigration office 
while I&#39;m waiting for my assessment hearing.

The combat&#39;s fine, such as it is; kinda has that 
overly ornate anime game problem where it feels

more like enemies are damaged from standing next 
to your attack animations and not because anything

actually hit them. I do like the mechanic where 
you absorb enemy souls and equip them to give

yourself new special attacks - I don&#39;t remember 
if this was a mechanic in Genshin Impact because

all my memories of that game reflexively 
shut down in self-defense, but whatever,

I liked this mechanic in Castlevania and I 
like it in this, too. The problem with it

is that if I want to swap out souls and try out 
different abilities, I need to go into the menu.

Which is like trying to walk through a sausage 
factory with large dogs attached to each limb.

It&#39;s not that it&#39;s badly designed and hard to 
navigate - although it absolutely is that - it&#39;s

just that I&#39;d go in to check one thing, and notice 
an indicator going &quot;You have new rewards to claim

in menu 27F!&quot; So I&#39;d go there and claim all of 
those and oh, now you have upgrades to spend

in menu 16 Omega Flamingo. So I&#39;d do that and 
&quot;Hooray! You succeeded at the spend ten upgrades

mission, claim your reward from menu Trousers 
Gazebo Fishslice! Now go to the Convene menu and

spend all the tokens we just gave you in the 
fruit machine then take your subsequent pile

of useless garbage for characters you don&#39;t use 
and refine them into upgrades for the sword you

actually have equipped. And by the time I stumbled 
bewildered back into gameplay with a whole extra

two points of damage night had fallen, wolves 
were stalking me and I couldn&#39;t remember where

I&#39;d parked. It was all clear, then. The combat, 
the grappling hook, the hot anime babes are not,

in fact, the soft play area attached to an 
immigration office, it&#39;s a soft play area

attached to a heroin dealer&#39;s house. It&#39;s all 
just been laid on to keep us freeloaders amused

while the whales get their fix. Free to play gacha 
games, not even once, kids. Worst case scenario,

you go into massive credit card debt. Best case, 
you waste your fucking time. If you want basic

catharsis combined with anime tits, there are 
perfectly good squeezeable mouse pads for that.
